item.title: By: HS
item.dc:creator: HS
item.description:
This is pretty compelling evidence that the hair gathered in tonsuring should not be considered an “idolatrous offering,” and therefore Jewish wig-wearers should feel comfortable using wigs built with such hair.
I’m sure there are many readers of this blog who would be in a position to present that opinion to people in influencing authority. And I am also confident that the people who distribute wig-hair from Tirumala to Jewish wig-makers would find very strong reason to hold onto this evidence to support their commercial enterprises.
That being said, most of the people who hold influence on the matter of “what’s a kosher sheitel” don’t know the difference between Tirumala and Tiramisu. So I suspect that the prejudice against such hair will pervade for generations to come.
It would be interesting to come back in a few years and use this as a case study to see whether reality can play a role in determining an halachic norm.
